item.title: Is the Aeneid a Celebration of Empire‚Äîor a Critique?
item.description:
I found Daniel Mendelsohn article in The New Yorker about The Aeneid to be engaging and fascinating.

What is the Aeneid about? It is about a tiny band of outcasts, the survivors of a terrible persecution. It is about how these survivors‚Äîclinging to a divine assurance that an unknown and faraway land will become their new home‚Äîarduously cross the seas, determined to refashion themselves as a new people, a nation of victors rather than victims. It is about how, when they finally get there, they find their new homeland inhabited by locals who have no intention of making way for them. It is about how this geopolitical tragedy generates new wars, wars that will, in turn, trigger further conflicts: bella horrida bella. It is about how such conflicts leave those involved in them morally unrecognizable, even to themselves. This is a story that both the Old and the New Worlds know too well; and Virgil was the first to tell it.

I disagree with the last sentence of the quote I pulled. The story the author describes is also the story of the Israelites in the Old Testament, which predates Virgil, though I‚Äôm not sure if Virgil could have known the stories. I‚Äôm sure the author intended us to think of that connection, though, based on how he wrote the passage. Consider me a little puzzled by this, but grateful to have read the article.
Ever since my son learned to use the word ‚Äúagain‚Äù, bedtime story time has become a lot more repetitive.

Wow, what a finish to the ALDS! I feared that the Red Sox were going to lose it due to Kimbrel‚Äôs 9th inning struggles. I enjoy late game excitement, but not when the team I root for suddenly implodes.
I am old and unhip now because I have not set up Siri Shortcuts to do anything yet.

item.title: Perfect Passwords
item.description: I still use GRC Perfect Passwords all the time to create new, randomly generated passwords‚Äìmostly because LastPass does not do a good job interacting with various website login forms. (I understand that is a challenge, especially when people like me run content blockers.) If anything, LastPass seems to work worse for me that it did a couple years ago.
I am excited about the Red Sox‚Äôs prospects in the ALDS. If only runs could carry over to the next game. üòÄ
üéµ Norah Jones has a new single out, which she wrote with Jeff Tweedy (who plays guitar on the track): A Song with No Name. It is bare, stark, and simple, like an old, sad country ballad.

item.title: Apple's New Proprietary Software Locks Kill Independent Repair on New MacBook Pros
item.description:
I used to be concerned about things like this, but now I accept it as part of the cost of doing business with Apple and on Apple platforms.

‚ÄúFor Macs with the Apple T2 chip, the repair process is not complete for certain parts replacements until the AST 2 System Configuration suite has been run. Failure to perform this step will result in an inoperative system and an incomplete repair,‚Äù the document reads. MacRumors reported the new policy earlier today.

I have built my own computers, run Linux (as well as Windows or Mac) as my primary operating system, run Android version based on AOSP, and have reached a point where I will gladly pay a single vendor for a more secure and consistent hardware and software experience. Admittedly, if Apple were a terrible company to do business with, I might not feel this way.
I wonder just how much of the Red Sox/Yankees series this weekend I will be able to watch.

I am on the iOS 12 beta on my iPad Pro, quite by accident (I forgot to disable the beta profile after iOS 12 was officially released). Disconnecting my Apple iPad SD card adapter will crash Photos and the entire OS about 50% of the time. üò• Be warned!

The orchard called these shiny yellow apples ‚ÄúYellow Ribbon‚Äù, which is either a variety name they made up, or something that Google has not yet encountered. I think they are really Golden Delicious.
Apple picking, when it‚Äôs early enough that no one else is around.
‚ÄúHow is The Good Place so Good?‚Äù This is relevant to my interests.

I don‚Äôt know why‚Äîand is surely isn‚Äôt healthy for me‚Äîbut I‚Äôm trying to figure out a better way to code settings screens on iOS. I find it incredibly tedious to do, whether using storyboards or pure Swift code. Of course, I have created nothing of value over two nights. üôÑ

item.title: Too many, and too few emoji
item.description:
Apple is adding more than 70 emoji in iOS 12.1.

While I don‚Äôt see that as a bad thing, I find emoji to be a lot more frustrating now that there are so many. Emoji has the same problem as other pictographic languages: there are far too many glyphs to know what you can express, and there are far too few glyphs to express everything you might want to say.

Apparently, I‚Äôm not the only one who thinks this way.
The past couple weeks I have fallen down the YouTube hole, watching as many photography tutorials as I can. I‚Äôm trying to learn how to shoot better with my new micro 4/3 camera.
My wife and I voted for the school budget today. It was the first time we brought the kids to the polls, which was fun. Hopefully the referendum will pass.
This sort of parade happens a lot around here.

I upgraded AnyList, the iOS grocery list app I use, to the Pro version once again, so I could use the Apple Watch app. It worked reallly well‚Äîfar better than it did a year ago. The watch app saved me from unpocketing and re-pocketing my phone about 39 times this evening. I‚Äôm pretty happy about that.

item.title: We Aren‚Äôt The Only Ones Who Like Apples
item.description: My family encountered a butterfly while apple-picking on Saturday.
Apple Pay is now accepted at CVS (at least my location). I‚Äôm surprised I didn‚Äôt read about this in the text press before I saw it today.
This is a Minnie toboggan, I think.
These mums, on our deck, are the only flower our deer friends have not eaten yet this week.
I liked this tree, which stands at the back of the pumpkin patch, but it was too big for me to fit into frame.
We will be returning to this pumpkin patch in about a week, I think.
Supermarket twilight
I heard Erin Ryan for the first time on the ‚ÄúPod Save America‚Äù podcast. She is smart and quick and great to listen to. I will check out her podcast ‚ÄúHysteria‚Äù soon.
Loon Mountain, New Hampshire
New Jersey
R.E.M.‚Äôs ‚ÄúAutomatic For the People‚Äù hits me so much harder as an adult than it did when I was in high school, despite the fact that I listened to it 1000% more often back then.
I don‚Äôt feel like I accomplished much this week, but I did ship two app updates, which is no small feat.

item.title: Wondering if the AnyList Apple Watch app is any good now
item.description: I‚Äôm debating whether I should pay for AnyList Pro again, just to use the Apple Watch app. I paid for a year a while back, and the Apple Watch app did not work very well. It kept crashing or getting killed, and would not stay in sync with my iPhone. None of the other paid features are interesting to me. I like the rest of the app‚Äôs features, though, and I‚Äôm getting the new Apple Watch in about a month, so maybe it will work this time. ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
SwiftoDo Desktop‚Äôs macOS Mojave update is stuck in App Review limbo for the time being. Hopefully it will get through shortly.

I wonder what it would be like if all the multi-exposure/HDR/Machine Learning technologies in the iPhone XS or Google Pixel were applied to a full frame camera with interchangeable lenses. Would that be the ultimate camera, in terms of picture quality? Would the technology not even work in that kind of camera for some reason? Would it work but not be necessary anymore? Are DSLRs more advanced than I even know, and do some of this stuff just as good as the latest iPhone or Pixel already?

Tonight I finally coded new and better input forms for Simple Call Blocker, my free iOS call blocking utility. The old ones were woefully amateurish (which I knew) and did not handle large text or small screen sizes too well.
‚öæÔ∏è 106 wins for the Red Sox! That‚Äôs a franchise record. I can‚Äôt believe it, at least compared to how they ended last season.

‚öæÔ∏è The last two Red Sox/Indians games felt like playoff baseball: close games, extra innings, nail-biting situations at the mound, etc. As a Red Sox fan, I hope my team can win a series against a team as good as the Indians (or, more importantly, the Yankees). Over the past week, I have been reminded of their actual playoff appearances the past two years, in which they lost in the divisional series.

My wife baked a delicious apple cake (yes, cake, not pie) this afternoon. We dusted it with confectioners sugar and topped it with whipped cream before serving. It was so good that my wife and daughter had seconds.
I‚Äôm launching my Mac for the first time in about a week tonight. It‚Äôs time to get back to coding and writing at night.
Autumn artwork with my daughter
X
Ocean Grove, New Jersey
New Jersey

Last night my wife and I watched the Mr. Rogers documentary Won‚Äôt You Be My Neighbor. It was wonderful and emotional film. Fred Rogers was a fascinating man. This interview he did with Terry Gross in 1985 is worth a listen, too.
Blog post: SwiftoDo Developer Notes, September 2018
It certainly felt hot today as I took my family to a town fair and planted mums. When does fall weather begin?
New Hampshire

item.title: I am very pleased with macOS Mojave.
item.description: It is not an exciting upgrade, I guess, but it is a solid one. Everything works. Everything is stable. Dark mode looks great and is useful. The Dock now has a second divider between pinned apps and running, non-pinned apps, which I like. Performance is just as good as with High Sierra on my 5-year-old MacBook Pro. All in all, macOS is a mature OS with a great amount of polish. While not exciting, and not substantially different from its predecessors, it represents the pinnacle of desktop operating systems (and shells).
Mojave‚Äôs dark mode is much nicer than I expected it to be. I am definitely going to support it in SwiftoDo Desktop. I‚Äôm working it out now.
Partly cloudy
